passages.text: Consumer | Global Retailing, Softlines & LUXURY Brands
Burlington Stores, Inc BURL| \(\) 280.30\(Outperform | Target Price/Base C\) \ \(370.00\) (from \(\) 310.00) Earnings Report
Company StatisticsMarket Capitalization (M)$16,86752-Week Range$115.66 - $267.58
1 Year Price History

Maintain Top 5 Rating on BURL, Expect P/E Expansion Across Office in the Near- Term: BURL's 2Q SSS accelerated the most vs Office peers on a 1- yr and 2- yr rate, with SSS accelerating \(+5pp\) on a 1- yr to \(+5\%\) (Marmaxx accelerated \(+1pp\) , ROST \(+2pp\) ). Separately, we think BURL accelerated the most intra- quarter with May at \(\sim +1\%\) and the quarter totaling to \(+5\%\) (suggesting July exit rate potentially \(\sim +7\%\) ). The \(+100bp\) GM beat was also impressive driven by Merch Margin \(+60bp\) (2- yr Merch Margin accelerated sequentially by \(+40bp\) despite the onset of tariffs) and SG&A leverage was better than expected, resulting in \(6.0\%\) EBIT margin for the quarter (Street \(4.6\%\) ; EVRe \(4.8\%\) ). EPS ex- items of \(\) 1.72\(vs. our\) \ \(1.33\) was a huge beat.

Raising Our 2025 EPS to \(\) 9.90\(from\) \ \(9.65\) , Street \(\) 9.24\(vs. Guide\) \ \(9.19\) to \(\) 9.59\(: BURL raised the high end of FY25 EPS guidance by \(+3\%\) though by less than the 2Q beat (adding \(\sim\) 0.13 of tariff cushion vs prior 2H guidance). Looking ahead to 3Q, in normal BURL practice, guidance is for SSS flat to \(+2\%\) . Just following the 2- year stack from 2Q would point to 3Q at \(+9\%\) ...BURL will beat significantly. Where we see upside:
1) Strong 2Q Exit Rate: We interpret BURL's comment of a "solid start" to 2Q as +low single digits (vs guide 0-2%). As such, we think July could've ended the quarter at \(\sim +7\%\) .

2) Deciphering BURL's "Solid 3Q Start": BURL suggested 3Q is off to a solid start (lapping SSS \(+6\%\) in the first six weeks of 3Q24). We assume August is \(\sim +3.5\%\) (lapping \(+6\%\) from August '24).

3) Easy Compares Ahead: After the first six weeks of 3Q24, weather became very unfavorable...we think BURL slowed to \(-1\%\) in Sept/Oct '24 from \(+6\%\) in Aug '24. Simply put, 2-year stack math suggests 3Q comps should beat guide materially with very easy compares ahead (and BURL is more weather sensitive than peers).
4) Strong Flow-Through: BURL delivered 40bp of upside per 1pp of SSS above its comp guide range for 2Q (typical algo is \(\sim 15bp\) of margin per point of comp).
We model 3Q EPS of \(\) 1.80\((Guide is\) \ \(1.50\) to \(\) 1.60\() largely driven

by our above- guide SSS of \(+4\%\) (Guide is flat to \(+2\%\) ) and corresponding margin flow through (we model 3Q EBIT margin of \(+40\) bp YOY; guide is down - 20bp to flat). Our 2025E EPS goes to \(\) 9.90\(from\) \ \(9.65\) prior; Street \(\) 9.24\(; Guide is\) \ \(9.19\) to \(\) 9.59\$

Key Debates Focus on Durability of Underlying Upside Drivers: BURL's updated outlook embeds 3Q EBIT margin change deteriorating to flat to down - 20bp YOY after 2Q margins expanded \(+120\) bp YOY. As we look through which margin drivers from 2Q should be sustainable in 2H, we think about:

1) 2Q AUR +MSD%: This was the biggest difference from TJX or ROST in our view (we think TJX likely had \(\sim 100\) bp of AUR, and ROST very slightly positive). Per BURL, AUR gains were primarily driven by better execution against its Better/Best strategy (very little from like-for-like pricing), as well as a little mix benefit (e.g. slower Home sales, which is a low AUR category). Some of those AUR gains should abate in 3Q as BURL is more able to acquire inventory in line with its historical category mix targets...but we wonder if BURL learned anything about the consumer response to its offering in 2Q that could support more durable AURs.
2) Freight: Some efficiency initiatives should stick, but this is somewhat tied to AUR as well (better efficiency per unit with higher AUR units flowing through the system).
3) Shrink: BURL took physical count in 2Q and shrink proved favorable. The accounting for that should support slight margin upside in 3Q as well (4Q will depend on another physical count).

4) Product Sourcing: While this was driven by BURL's supply chain efficiency strategies, we'd remind that there was an Occupancy true-up in 2H24 (lease renewal at a higher rate) that should roll off in 2H25.

5) Store Level SG&A Savings: BURL notes that this wasn't labor cuts that need to be restored with comps re-accelerating, and was more due to BURL 2.0 process improvement initiatives driving more efficient in store processes.

Adding It Up... Multi- year trends and easy compares ahead should support SSS well above Street at \(+2.6\%\) in 3Q and \(+1.9\%\) in 4Q. On margins, we think many of the initiatives that drove margin upside—and upside to BURL's historical flow- through algo—should continue in 3Q. The only caution we see is that a surprising AUR upside story in 3Q could diminish as merchandising normalizes and even though BURL has high packaways today (+43% YOY) that were largely bought before tariffs...at some point those run out and margin tailwinds will be tougher to come by. But we see significant upside to 2025, and we raise our 2025E EPS to \(\) 9.90\(from\) \ \(9.65\) prior (guide: \(\) 9.19- \ \(9.59\) , Street was \(\) 9.24\() and reiterate Outperform.

EVR Estimates: We model 3Q EPS of \(\) 1.80\(prior:\) \ \(1.85\) ; Street: \(\) 1.67\(; Guide is\) \ \(1.50\) to \(\) 1.60\(on SSS + 4\%\) prior: \(+3\%\) ; Street: \(+3\%\) ; Guide is flat to \(+2\%\) , GM 43.7% (unchanged; Street: 43.7%), and SG&A at 34.5% of net sales (prior 34.3%; Street 34.9%). Our 2025 EPS goes to \(\) 9.90\(prior:\) \ \(9.65\) ; Street: \(\) 9.24\(; Guide is\) \ \(9.19\) to \(\) 9.59\(). Maintain 2026 EPS of\) \ \(11.80\) (Street: \(\) 11.01\$

Valuation: Raise our Target Price to \(\) 370\(based on 26x our FY27E EPS. Our prior Target of\) \ \(310\) was based on the same 26x P/E multiple, but we've rolled the base year forward to be off of 2027 (from 2026 prior).
Figure 1: EVRlSle vs.Consensus Estimates
Source:FactSet, Company Data,Evercore ISI Research
Our \(\) 370\(target price is based on\) \sim 26x \(our 2027E EPS.\)
Increased competition, economic slowdown, lack of inventory availability

Time of dissemination: August 28 2025 3:25 PM ET

Evercore ISI's recommendations are based on a stock's total forecasted return over the next 12 months. Total forecasted return is equal to the expected percentage price return plus gross dividend yield. We divide our stocks under coverage into three primary ratings categories, with the following return guidelines:

Outperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be greater than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector. In Line- the total forecasted return is expected to be in line with the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector. Underperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be less than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector. Coverage Suspended- the rating and target price have been removed pursuant to Evercore ISI policy when Evercore is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving this company and in certain other circumstances. Rating Suspended- Evercore ISI has suspended the rating and target price for this stock because there is not sufficient fundamental basis for determining, or there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints around publishing, a rating or target price. The previous rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this company and should not be relied upon.
Prior to October 10, 2015, the "Coverage Suspended" and "Rating Suspended" categories were included in the category "Suspended."

FINRA requires that members who use a ratings system with terms other than "Buy," "Hold/Neutral" and "Sell" to equate their own ratings to these categories. For this purpose, and in the Evercore ISI ratings distribution below, our Outperform, In Line, and Underperform ratings can be equated to Buy, Hold and Sell, respectively.
